description: Onomatopoeic, perhaps borrowed; compare German bummen, Dutch bommen (“to hum, buzz”).

entries.meaning: A low-pitched, resonant sound, such as of an explosion.
A rapid expansion or increase.
examples: You should prepare for the coming boom in the tech industry.

entries.meaning: (aviation) Ellipsis of sonic boom.
One of the calls of certain monkeys or birds.
examples: Interestingly, the blue monkey's boom and pyow calls are both long-distance signals (Brown, 1989), yet the two calls differ in respect to their susceptibility to habitat-induced degradation.

entries.meaning: (chess engines) An instance of booming.

verbs.description: boom (third-person singular simple present booms, present participle booming, simple past and past participle boomed)

entries.meaning: To make a loud, hollow, resonant sound.
examples: Thunder boomed in the distance and lightning flashes lit up the horizon.
The cannon boomed, recoiled, and spewed a heavy smoke cloud.
Beneath the cliff, the sea was booming on the rocks.
I can hear the organ slowly booming from the chapel.

entries.meaning: (transitive, figuratively, of speech) To exclaim with force, to shout, to thunder.
Of a Eurasian bittern, to make its deep, resonant territorial vocalisation.
(transitive) To make something boom.
examples: Men in grey robes slowly boom the drums of death.

entries.meaning: (aviation) To subject to a sonic boom.
(slang, US, obsolete) To publicly praise.
examples: If you pull this off every paper in England and America will be booming you.

entries.meaning: To rush with violence and noise, as a ship under a press of sail, before a free wind.
examples: She comes booming down before it.

entries.meaning: (chess engines) To rapidly adjust the evaluation of a position away from zero, indicating a likely win or loss.

description: Borrowed from Dutch boom (“tree; pole”). Doublet of beam.

entries.meaning: (sailing) A spar extending the foot of a sail; a spar rigged outboard from a ship's side to which boats are secured in harbour.
A movable pole used to support a microphone or camera.
(by extension) A microphone supported on such a pole.
A horizontal member of a crane or derrick, used for lifting.
(electronics) The longest element of a Yagi antenna, on which the other, smaller ones are transversally mounted.
A floating barrier used to obstruct navigation, for military or other purposes; or used for the containment of an oil spill or to control the flow of logs from logging operations.
A wishbone-shaped piece of windsurfing equipment.
The section of the arm on a backhoe closest to the tractor.
A gymnastics apparatus similar to a balance beam.

verbs.description: boom (third-person singular simple present booms, present participle booming, simple past and past participle boomed)

entries.meaning: To extend, or push, with a boom or pole.
(usually with "up" or "down") To raise or lower with a crane boom.

description: Perhaps a figurative development of Etymology 1, above.

entries.meaning: (economics, business) A period of prosperity, growth, progress, or high market activity.

verbs.description: boom (third-person singular simple present booms, present participle booming, simple past and past participle boomed)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To flourish, grow, or progress.
examples: The population boomed in recent years.

entries.meaning: (transitive, dated) To cause to advance rapidly in price.
examples: to boom railroad or mining shares
